skills.name: Add integers up to 2 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed
Add integers up to 2 digits using a written method where carrying is needed
Subtract integers up to 2 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed
Subtract integers up to 2 digits using a written method where carrying is needed

explanations.A: 4 is smaller than 7 so we borrow 10 and do 14 - 7 = 7 for the ones digit. That leaves 5 - 2 = 3 for the tens digit, so the final answer is 37.
explanations.B: I think you forgot to reduce the number in the column that you borrowed from. If you have 6 tens and you take one to make 14 in the ones column, then you will only have 5 tens left.Â
explanations.C: You have done 64 + 27 but this question is 64 - 27.
explanations.D: You have subtracted 4 from 7 because it's smaller, but you need to subtract all of 27 from all of 64. Try borrowing 10 so that you can start with 14 - 7 for the ones digit.

explanations.A: You have subtracted 3 from 8 because it's smaller, but you need to subtract all of 18 from all of 73. Try borrowing 10 so that you can start with 13 - 8 for the ones digit.
explanations.B: 3 is smaller than 8 so we borrow 10 and do 13 - 8 = 5 for the ones digit. That leaves 6 - 1 = 5 for the tens digit, so the final answer is 55.
explanations.C: Almost! I think you rounded 18 to 20 and subtracted from 73. 73 - 20 = 53. But then you subtracted 2 rather than add 2.
explanations.D: You have done 73 + 18 but this question is 73 - 18.

explanations.A: You have done 75 - 18, but this question is 75 + 18.
explanations.B: Almost! I think you forgot to carry the 10. 5 + 8 = 13, so we have an extra 10 to add up with the 70 and 10...
explanations.C: Not quite - I think you started counting up on 75 instead of 76. Count 76, 77, 78, ... Or add 10 and then 8.
explanations.D: 5 + 8 = 13 so the ones digit is 3 and we carry the ten into the next column. 7 + 1 + 1 = 9 tens, so the final answer is 93.

explanations.A: Almost! I think you forgot to carry the 10. 6 + 7 = 13, so we have an extra 10 to add up with the 40 and 20...
explanations.B: Not quite - I think you started counting up on 46 instead of 47. Count 47, 48, 49, ... Or add 20 and then 7.
explanations.C: 6 + 7 = 13 so the ones digit is 3 and we carry the ten into the next column. 4 + 2 + 1 = 7 tens, so the final answer is 73.
explanations.D: You have done 46 - 27, but this question is 46 + 27.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you subtracted rather than added.
explanations.B: Starting in the right hand column 4 + 3 = 7. Moving to the left we have 6 + 3 = 9.
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you counted your starting number when adding on. So when adding 3 to 4, remember it's 5, 6, 7.
explanations.D: I think you made a tiny slip. Just check 6 + 3.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you subtracted rather than added.
explanations.B: Starting in the right hand column 6 + 3 = 9. Moving to the left we have 5 + 3 = 8
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you counted your starting number when adding on. So when adding 3 to 6, remember it's 7, 8, 9.
explanations.D: I think you made a tiny slip. Just check 5 + 3.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you added by mistake.
explanations.B: I think you made a mistake when counting back. Remember when doing 9 - 2, you would go back one to 8, and then one to 7.
explanations.C: Starting in the right column 9 - 2 is 7. Moving to the left 7 - 4 is 3.
explanations.D: I think you made a tiny slip. Check 7 - 4.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you added by mistake.
explanations.B: I think you made a tiny slip. Check 5 - 2.
explanations.C: I think you made a mistake when counting back. Remember when doing 6 - 3, you would go back one to 5, then one to 4, and then one to 3.
explanations.D: Starting in the right column 6 - 3 is 3. Moving to the left 5 - 2 is 3.

explanations.A: Almost. I think you spotted that they had to borrow for the subtraction in the right hand column, but you made the first number 1 bigger rather than 1 smaller
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you added 5 and 3, but remember 1 was borrowed for the units column.
explanations.C: 5 + 3 is 8, but 1 was borrowed for the units column subtraction, so you need to add that back on, giving 9.
explanations.D: I think you did 5 - 3. Remember we want to know what we would have subtracted from to get a 3 in the tens column. Make sure you take into account the 1 that is borrowed for the units column.

explanations.A: I think you did 4 - 3. Remember we want to know what we would have subtracted from to get a 3 in the tens column. Make sure you take into account the 1 that is borrowed for the units column.
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you added 4 and 3, but remember 1 was borrowed for the units column.
explanations.C: 4 + 3 is 7, but 1 was borrowed for the units column subtraction, so you need to add that back on, giving 8.
explanations.D: Almost. I think you spotted that they had to borrow for the subtraction in the right hand column, but you made the first number 1 bigger rather than 1 smaller
